Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Superconducting Nanowires and Graphene Junctions Using a Coplanar Fabry-Perot Microwave Resonator as a Qubit Device
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

Recently, it became clear that quantum mechanics, which is traditionally used to describe individual and small groups of elementary particles (e.g., electrons and atoms), can also predict the behavior of the so-called "mesoscopic" objects, i.e. systems containing a large number of atoms like large molecules or nanodevices. The goal of this project is to investigate how the laws of quantum mechanics apply to nanowires. These nanowires are metallic cylinders having a diameter of a few billionth of a meter. The project will explore nanowires made out of superconducting metals. The scientific question to be addressed is the applicability of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle to the electrical current and electrical charge in nanodevices involving nanowires. The most advanced nanoscience and nanotechnology will be used to fabricate such wires. The measurements on nanowires will be done using a novel experimental approach, namely a nanowire will be inserted into a special type of microwave resonator called a microwave superconducting Fabry-Perot resonator. This project will explore the possibility of using the hybrid nanowire-resonator devices as qubits, the quantum mechanical analog of the classical "bit" that stores information in a computer. This project will support the education of graduate students in these advanced technologies, which will prepare them for scientific careers in academia and in our most advanced technology industries. Undergraduate students will also participate in the project, gaining training and hands-on experience in the most advanced scientific research. The project will also provide training to a postdoc.


****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

Recently, it became clear that macroscopic degrees of freedom, such as electrical current, can be described by laws of quantum mechanics for so-called mesoscopic systems: for example quantum mechanics is important for describing results of transport measurements in systems involving large molecules, nanoparticles, or superconducting nanodevices. The goal of this project is to investigate how the laws of macroscopic quantum mechanics apply to superconducting nanowires. In particular, quantum phase slips will be investigated. A novel experimental approach will be used, namely the nanowires will be coupled to a superconducting microwave Fabry-Perot resonator. Such a hybrid device will provide complementary experimental information when compared with traditional dc electrical transport measurements. The nanowires are expected to act as nonlinear kinetic inductors. This project will explore the possibility of using the hybrid nanowire-resonator devices as qubits. Such nanowire-qubits should be free of the decoherence mechanisms affecting Josephson tunnel junction so far employed for superconducting qubits. The nanowires will be fabricated and imaged by the most advanced nanotechnology. The measurements will be carried out using ultra-low-temperature refrigerators and ultra-low-noise microwave measurements. This project will support the education of graduate students in these advanced technologies, which will prepare them for scientific careers in academia and in our most advanced technology industries. Undergraduate students will also participate in the project, gaining training and hands-on experience in the most advanced scientific research. The project will also provide training to a postdoc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Superconducting wires are physical systems that possess the extraordinary property of supporting an electrical current without any dissipation. They thus appear to realize a form of perpetual motion. This basic description of superconductivity, however, must be refined. Dissipation in a superconducting wire actually occurs, but only in finite bursts, and these bursts are so extremely rare in an ordinary metallic wire well below the superconducting transition temperature that they practically almost never occur in a realistic experiment. On the other hand, when a burst does occur in a wire into which a constant current is forced, the wire is suddenly traversed by a flux quantum, meaning that the integral of the voltage appearing across the wire is exactly given by a fundamental constant whose value is Planck's constant divided by twice the electron charge. The factor of two in the elementary charge corresponds to the fact that superconductivity is an ordered state of matter in which conduction electrons condense in pairs. The order parameter of a superconducting wire is subject to a full twist when the flux burst occurs and such bursts are usually known as phase slips. If we now turn to wires that are so small that they contain only very few channels for conduction, the quantum phase slips can become so frequent, even at the lowest temperature, as to become measurable and  set a limit to how dissipation-less the wire can be. At high temperatures, the phase slips are thermally activated, but at very low temperature, quantum fluctuations can be the dominant process leading to phase slips. This regime takes place in superconducting "nanowires", i.e. wires with nanometric dimensions for their width and thickness. These systems pose a fundamental problem: can the quantum phase slips occur coherently over the whole length of the wire (coherent quantum phase slips, a process abbreviated as CQPS)? If this process existed, then a superconducting wire would turn into an insulator at low temperature. In this context, the aim of the project was to shed light on the physics of superconducting nanowires by coupling them to a microwave resonator, which can be interrogated at high speed and thus reveal the quantum phase slip process.

In the experiments we have performed for the project, a system equivalent to a nanowire was created from a 1D array of Josephson tunnel junctions. Each junction can be the center of a phase slip. On purpose, one junction was made weaker than the others, to control where the phase slip would occur. The quantum nature of the phase slips was ensured by the fact that the coherence of the circuit is extremely high as a result of the junction dissipation-free quality and its very low radiation damping. As a consequence of the quantum phase slips, the circuit behaves as a two-level atom when the loop formed by the array is biased by an external field threading one half-flux quantum. By coupling this artificial atom, nicknamed fluxonium, to an on-chip resonator, we can probe the dynamics of the quantum phase slip through the spectroscopy of the artificial atom levels.

Our results have shown that the quantum phase slip rates depend on the parameters of the system in the very peculiar manner that has been predicted theoretically. They also have established experimentally a fundamental superconductivity dissipation phenomenon predicted by Brian Josephson in 1962: quasiparticle-Cooper pair interference.

In summary, the very existence of coherent quantum phase slips (CQPS) is an issue which has been hotly debated in the last ten years in the field of superconductivity. Basically, CQPS is the physical mechanism by which a one-dimensional superconductor would turn into an insulator, at T=0, when its length would go to infinity.
